Thinning out Lumen positionOriginally bought as high dividend value play. Since it is changing focus significantly, deserves a revaluation. Recent sales of business segments sounded promising as assets were sold off at good metrics. Selling off a lot of near term cashflow. Problem is that company is threatening to waste proceeds on new "growth" markets. Company has no real track record in growth. Would much prefer if proceeds were used to either paydown debt or buyback stock. While company tries to paint new investments as an extension of its business, it appears to be moving into more dynamic growth areas from a high cashflow no growth utility telecom/networking business. The businesses it is moving toward are not bad businesses. The problem is that I have no faith in current management being able to make the switch. If I want to invest in these businesses, I would prefer a management team with a track record of success. In general, I am in a reducing market exposure mode and therefore am looking more for what to trim than what to acquire.Msg 177341 of 177341 at 9/22/2021 10:34:19 AM by Zver1

Could someone explain this to me? I understand calls and puts and that a sweep is a large purchase or sale.Regarding LUMN (NYSE:LUMN), we observe a call option sweep with bearish sentiment. It expires in 63 day(s) on November 19, 2021. Parties traded 491 contract(s) at a $13.00 strike. This particular call needed to be split into 36 different trades to become filled. The total cost received by the writing party (or parties) was $34.7K, with a price of $69.0 per contract. There were 7298 open contracts at this strike prior to today, and today 597 contract(s) were bought and sold.

Lumen Technologies (NYSE:LUMN) saw some choppy midday trading and is now holding steady down 2.5% after a positive shout from Gilman Hill's Jenny Harrington on CNBC's Halftime Report.After a deep reassessment last week of its original investment thesis, the firm is still in the same bullish place: "The fiber assets are hugely valuable and underappreciated," she says.Management is at an inflection point where they're really trying to unlock the value of those assets, she says, adding "We think that it's probably trading at about 50% of what its private market value equivalent would be."Lumen trading volume today of 10.8 million shares is just short of surpassing its average full-day volume of 11.18 million shares.The shares have declined 24% from a summer high of $15.45.And that means forward dividend yield is sitting at 8.24%. All of the other stocks in my portfolio went up over two percentage points... some hit gains of over 5%... except this ONE. It makes me wonder why I should stay long with LUMN. I have not yet seen any evidence of significant strategic goals that will lead to significant gains. As a leader of fiber optic miles that make up the backbone of the Internet for North America, I'd expect more.Or, there is that notion of being bought out by another company... on the cheap. Is the reason Lumen isn’t getting more awards for government contracts, due to their network still having a lot of Huawei gear?Among that response you mentioned: “last I heard, the "legacy" Level 3 network contains alot of Huawei kit: if that's still the case, given that Huawei's big push is to have the West buy more of its equipment, I think Level 3/LUMN would be low on the list of China's retaliation targets.” Is this still the case? Do you know the limits of Huawei gear in telecom and Lumen specifically? I’ve read clear statements by Verizon that they don’t use any Huawei stuff. And two things I have read on this were that most telecom providers didn’t either: “None of the US’s "big four" wireless carriers—AT&T, Verizon, Sprint, and T-Mobile—use Huawei equipment, Huawei executive Tim Danks confirmed earlier this year. (2019 - ed) Neither do cable internet providers Comcast or Charter.“ And more recently, the article referenced by thinkith showed a clip where England is replacing Huawei stuff with Nokia components, and then this statement: “The U.K. government has banned installation of Huawei’s 5G equipment in the country as of this month, and has demanded operators remove all of such equipment by 2027.“ So my question: if Lumen still has a lot of Huawei gear in their network, is that holding back any award of any government contracts?

Johnbadhands wrote this today:I am sure LUMN's assets will one day be in demand and critical. The problem is, where is the evidence that they will be able to extract any pricing power out of this? Look at their previous IRUs where they gave away their assets essentially for free. The risk of this happening again is certainly not zero, because all indications are that it is a buyer's market. Look at telecom that continue to pour billions into 3G, 4G, 5G while piling on debt - all of these services become essential but the translation into increased profits is weak. LUMN has established partnerships with a lot of massive companies but even lumped all together it's not moving the needle. Either demand remains anemic or they got hosed on the deals, or both. I'm also confused on what the continual endless capex spend is being used on. The edge is now reaching 97% of US enterprise. I was under the impression that they have "future-proofed" a lot of their buildout with empty conduits etc. Why not conserve capex at this point, buy back shares if the future is actually as inevitable as you say, and wait for the demand to actually show up before spending more? That is what a smart management team would do at this point.

Lumen Technologies declares quarterly cash dividendDENVER, Aug. 19, 2021 /PRNewswire/ -- Lumen Technologies (NYSE: LUMN) today announced that its Board of Directors voted to declare a regular quarterly cash dividend of 25 cents per share. The dividend is payable September 10, 2021, to shareholders of record at the close of business on August 30, 2021. The ex-dividend date will be August 27, 2021.

The Lumen CEO needs to go, he is out of his league, everything he touches is tainted by the incompetence he has put on full display since the day he told LVLT shareholders that merging with Lumen would produce a transformational tech company with surging revenues. The proxy put out for the combination of CTL & LVLT said 28 billion in revenue for 2020. It missed the mark by 30%. It was partially authored and certainly embraced by the NOW Lumen CEO. Maybe he didn't DO due diligence like one would expect from a CEO who tells his shareholders a deal is a GOOD move?! Wall Street has been on to this incompetence from the get go and all of their analysis has played out in real time since the deal closed. This then became a momentum play when it was clear that trust had been broken in the early days of the current CEO telling tall tails about divy sustainability, cutting of unprofitable revenue, enterprise, enabling the 4th industrial revolution, low latency, edge and now mass market opportunities in the footprint retained in the recent Apollo deal... The incompetence has remained on full display as it would appear the plan has been formulated and changes quarterly with a dartboard being the main determining factor.. To be crystal clear. I believe the assets have value. That being said, the numerous articles and comments for the past 3-4 years supporting Lumen at a much higher valuation have ALL ignored the same thing. They have ignored the outsized role played by Lumen leadership and these multigenerational lows in PPS. Current leadership needs to be retired or replaced through sale of the company for shareholder to reap the benefits of these assets. Going on 4 years, how anyone can still believe in current leadership is beyond me.

Whether the two assets sell or not, the Company remains a FCF Machine in anticipation of what can clearly be states as "closer than ever" exponential top line growth. The exercise has proved the remaining value of the company by most conservative "multiples" is worth significantly more than the quote being bandied about in our faces today.BofA was involved with the sale of those TWO less attractive assets with significantly higher multiples than the whole company "balance" of higher growth assets are trading for today, yet they put out an $8.00 Target yesterday.There are people inside there as well as MS who need to go to JAIL for this.

I was under the impression that Lumen has built/acquired one of the most expansive and future-proof low-latency fiber networks in the country that reaches 98%+ of businesses. I was also under the impression that the edge compute buildout is nearing completion and also reaches a similar percentage of enterprise. What do they keep spending capex on? They can carry on their FTTH buildout with their previous microtargeting strategy rather than going crazy at a time when there are multiple downgrades and an apparent pricing war brewing. This is the perfect time to reign in spending, clean up your balance sheet even more and focus on shareholder return. Look at the how the oil and gas industry suffered for years due to overbuild and oversupply. But as soon as their existence was threatened they started to cut supply, shelve projects and direct cash flow to debt paydown and share buybacks. Look at what's happening with commodities going through the roof due to structural undersupply and several companies 10x from their lows. A similar thing happened in the semiconductor industry where the big players managed their supply and have now created a strong pricing environment on their way to record revenues and profits. There is a lesson to be learned here, but it looks like the telecom industry is run by a bunch of dinosaurs who don't understand the basics of supply and demand. by johnbadhands

This whole thread is about edge computing. In that context 5ms refers to the time it takes light to travel from an edge compute location to a user. And the part of the network mostly traversed is the access network. Not the long haul network. Depending on where Lumen has placed the edge nodes it is possible that some long haul fiber is traversed, but extremely unlikely. As such that press release holds little to no relevance to the edge compute service.

Lumen volume jumps as CNBC analyst sees big upside in fiber assetsOct. 27, 2021 2:04 PM ETLumen Technologies, Inc. (LUMN)By: Jason Aycock, SA News Editor1 CommentLumen Technologies (NYSE:LUMN) saw some choppy midday trading and is now holding steady down 2.5% after a positive shout from Gilman Hill's Jenny Harrington on CNBC's Halftime Report.After a deep reassessment last week of its original investment thesis, the firm is still in the same bullish place: "The fiber assets are hugely valuable and underappreciated," she says.Management is at an inflection point where they're really trying to unlock the value of those assets, she says, adding "We think that it's probably trading at about 50% of what its private market value equivalent would be."Lumen trading volume today of 10.8 million shares is just short of surpassing its average full-day volume of 11.18 million shares.The shares have declined 24% from a summer high of $15.45.And that means forward dividend yield is sitting at 8.24%.
